title: Is dissolving sugar in water a reversible change? - Quora

response.answer_text: Yes but it’s not straightforward. If it was salt instead of sugar you could just heat the solution to drive off the water leaving salt crystals. If you wanted you could also condense the steam being given off and collect the water too. Sugar isn’t like that. If you heat a sugar solution some of the water boils away but instead of nice crystals you get a concentrated sugar syrup. If you keep heating that the sugar will burn. The trick is to heat the sugar solution in a vacuum. The water boils away at a lower temperature, doesn’t burn and gives you nice white sugar crystals. Industrially this is how white sugar is made.

Dissolving sugar in water is an example of a reversible change. Why i would tell you that chemical change produces new chemical products. In order for sugar in water to be a chemical change, something new would need to result. A chemical reaction would have to occur. However, mixing sugar and water simply produces... sugar in water! The substances may change form, but not identity. That's a physical reversible change.

Yes. If you evaporate the water, you will get sugar residue at the bottom. This is the principle behind the water purification process called distillation: By evaporating water, very little or no dissolved substances remain in it, making it safe to drink.

Dissolving sugar in water is a physical change. You can tell this because if you were to dissolve the sugar in water and then let the water evaporate, the sugar would still be left. Hope this was helpful to u…. Good luck…
